content.description: On the south face of the east twin, traverse the handrail to it's end and move up to the lip and the slab above.  A good amount of climbing with little danger.  You can also go straight up from the good jug in the middle of the rail.  One of the best on these boulders.

There are two boulders here - the East Twin and West Twin. This route is on the Northwest arete of the East Twin.

Sit down start leads to a huge reach up and left.  From there, cut your feet loose and begin an improbable sequence up the arete.

Benningfield's book gives this a V4 rating, so I stuck with that.  However, it felt significantly harder than the V5 so maybe a hold broke or I am missing something.  Anyway, this problem is burly!

Well, it's on the northeast arete of the west twin...the standup is good, but the real money in in the sitdown.  Start on the obvious sloper, and either move up and left to the beautful slopers, then toss right to join the standup, or move up and right through a really small crimp and toss left into the standup (about V7 either way).

There are two boulders here - the East Twin and the West Twin.  This route starts on the left side of the East Twin, on the North Face.  It is a sit down start with an obvious big jug as the starting hold.

The crux is right here, moving up and right.  Perfect flat landing on pine needles if you fall. The moves then ease off for a bit and then get tricky just before starting up a V1 slab.

The top out here is pretty high, so be careful.

There are two boulders here - the East Twin and the West Twin.This line is on the North Face of the East Twin, right in the center.  It is just left of the big pine tree, and is the same line as the V5 if you skip the sds and the traverse across the boulder.  Again, topping out is way off the ground, so be careful.
